What should you do after formatting the EBS volume?
After formatting the EBS volume, you should mount it on /data and then change the owner to ec2-user: ec2-user. You can refer to the AWS documentation if you do not know how to mount it.
What repositories should be downloaded for this setup?
You should download the MXNet repository and the TensorFlow models repository. This can be done by navigating to /data and using the git clone commands provided.
Why is it important to install OpenCV for this setup?

It is important to install OpenCV (both 3.x and 4.x work well) because without it, you cannot convert ImageNet raw data to RecordIO files. This is because the im2rec.py script utilizes some OpenCV functions. You can refer to a guide on how to install OpenCV on Ubuntu for assistance.

What is the goal of the document?

The goal of the document is to provide guidance for people who need distributed GPU training using Horovod for experimental purposes. It recommends viewing Julien Simon’s article and AWS Documentation for additional information and troubleshooting.
What type of instances are recommended for data preparation and data transformation versus distributed training?

For data preparation and data transformation, cheaper instances like t2.large with 1.0TB EBS volume are recommended. For distributed training, multiple GPU instances like p2, p3, g3, and g4 are needed.

What are the different storage paths for the ImageNet dataset mentioned in the text?

The different storage paths for the ImageNet dataset mentioned are: s3://dataset-image/imagenet/raw (raw jpeg), s3://dataset-image/imagenet/tfrecord (TFRecord before resizing), s3://dataset-image/imagenet/tfrecord-resized (TFRecord after resizing to 224x224), and s3://dataset-image/imagenet/recordio (RecordIO after resizing to 256x256).
Why was the ImageNet dataset not resized to 224x224 in one of the storage paths?

The ImageNet dataset was not resized to 224x224 in one of the storage paths because an article showed different validation accuracy for resizing strategies. The article can be found at https://forums.fast.ai/t/impact-of-image-resizing-on-model-training-time-and-performance/1980.
What are the steps for setting up an EC2 instance for data transformation of the ImageNet dataset?

The steps for setting up an EC2 instance for data transformation of the ImageNet dataset include creating an EC2 instance (Ubuntu 18.04 or 16.04, with t2.micro available but t2.large recommended due to memory size), and creating an EBS volume (1.0TB) for the ImageNet dataset to attach to the EC2 instance. The ImageNet dataset consists of 138GB for the training set and 6.3GB for the validation set, but additional space is needed.

What is the first step to prepare the validation set for ImageNet?

The first step is to create a directory named 'validation' using the command `$ mkdir validation`, then move the file `ILSVRC2012_img_val.tar` into the 'validation' directory with `$ mv ILSVRC2012_img_val.tar validation`, and finally change into the 'validation' directory with `$ cd validation`.
How do you extract the contents of the validation set tar file?
You extract the contents of the validation set tar file by using the command `$ tar xf ILSVRC2012_img_val.tar` after navigating to the 'validation' directory.
What should be done after extracting the validation set?

After extracting the validation set, you should move the jpeg files (e.g., ILSVRC2012_val_00000001.JPEG to ILSVRC2012_val_00050000.JPEG) into 1,000 directories, each representing a unique category, using the provided script from the URL: https://github.com/juliensimon/aws/blob/master/mxnet/imagenet/build_validation_tree.sh.

What type of EC2 instance is recommended for training with distributed GPU using Uber's Horovod or Tensorflow's DistributedStrategy?

For training with distributed GPU using Uber's Horovod or Tensorflow's DistributedStrategy, it is recommended to use p3.16xlarge or p3dn.24xlarge EC2 instances with Deep Learning AMI (Ubuntu 16.04) or Deep Learning AMI (Amazon Linux).
What is the default root volume size for the recommended EC2 instances, and what is the suggested size?

The default root volume size for the recommended EC2 instances is 75GB, but it is suggested to increase it to 100GB since training logs and model checkpoints are stored in the root volume if the training configuration is not modified.
What can you do if you do not want to increase the root volume size of the EC2 instance?
If you do not want to increase the root volume size of the EC2 instance, you can delete some conda environments such as Theano, Chainer, Caffe, and Caffe2 after logging in to the EC2 instance.
